title: Reachability and Learning for Hybrid Systems

author: Claire J. Tomlin, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences, UC Berkeley

segmentation: I'm coming from the control theory community and I would say in the past two years I've been working more and more on incorporating different reinforcement learning algorithms into what we've been building in control.
So what I'm going to talk to you today about is joint work with a number of people, but mostly two PhD students at Berkeley Kaneaki, Metallo and Jamie Physic.
OK, so I'm going to use as motivation a problem that I've been working on for a long time with NASA and the FAA in the US.
It's on automating air traffic control systems, so here's 2 pictures.

This is the sort of same timeframe of showing flights over Oakland Center which covers most of Northern California and a lot of the Pacific Ocean and what we're showing here are both cross traffic high altitude flights.

As well as the merging traffic coming into San Francisco airport and basically what I want to illustrate here is the the structure in the airspace so the aircraft are flying along well defined routes that are defined by routes between navigation points and then also you know when they're coming into airports.
They're merging along fairly well traveled routes, so there's quite a lot of structure that's being used by human air traffic controllers to route these aircraft.
It's a very human centered control system right now, so all of the movements of the aircraft are controlled by air traffic controllers who talked to pilots over radio links.

If you zoom into the control system on each aircraft, it's also very structured, so this just shows sort of a diagram of merging traffic coming into one route, and what controllers tend to do is they tend to use a fairly small number of discrete control modes to control the aircraft, so they typically control the aircraft it's flying at a speed which is optimal for the altitude that it's flying at, and then if there's a necessity to avoid conflict with other aircraft, which is the primary job of air traffic controllers, is to maintain separation between aircraft.
They'll speed it up or slow it down, put it into a detour or shortcut.

Kind of the last resort is a holding pattern, but the air traffic a good air traffic controller will touch every aircraft at most once, and usually when it enters the controllers sector of air space to be able to maybe deviated a little bit so it doesn't lose separation with any other aircraft, and so it's a.
It's a big cognitive is.
It's a very interesting cognitive problem for air traffic.
Controllers, what they tend to do.
So we spent a lot of time sitting behind air traffic controllers and watching what they do and talking to them.
They tend to group aircraft together by potential conflict.
So if they have all the aircraft flying along a single route at the same speed, that's basically just like controlling one aircraft.
So it's a very simple cognitive thing to do.
This is kind of the most cognitive load is these two aircraft, or potentially going to lose separation, so they'll focus on deviating one or two of those aircraft.
This is another group of aircraft that they'll group together and.
Treat together.
Now it's.

A really interesting time for air traffic control because now more and more businesses are interested in putting their small UAV's up into the air space and NASA and the FAA are very interested in designing what they called a UTM unmanned air system traffic management to basically make the air traffic control system more flexible for these small aircraft.
So in thinking about, for example, what Amazon and Google are proposing to do, it's natural to think about maintaining some of the structure of the current air space.
So still the same or similar route structures at different altitudes.
You know, separated from the big aircraft.
Probably very simple control mode, so the humans in the loop understand what's going on.
So basically safety and simplicity.
But also these are going to be autonomous systems, so they need to have the ability to adapt to new information.
And that's really where the learning comes in.
